advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (AUGUST 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for the Yannick Noah Tennis cartridge. The game is only called "Grand Slam Tennis" on the Emerson Arcadia 2001, but in France was marketed with the most famous french tennis player's name, Yannick Noah.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">... One of the results is our new identity and our new product: the Intersystems DPS-1. An IEEE S-100 compatible mainframe with features that live up to its look. <i>Dependable</i> operation to 4 Mhz. Twenty-card capacity, a modular power supply. And something no one else has: built-in break points to give you a faster, more powerful tool for testing software as well as hardware...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a German advertisement for the BIT-60 and BIT-90 models. Atari VCS-2600 cartridges are scattered in front of the BIT-60 to show that the it is really compatible with the VCS-2600 ! But strangely enough, there is no picture displayed on the TV. Were these models really working ? ;-)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #5</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/" target="_blank">Soichiro's Oga</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (MAY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Computing pret-a-porter" <br><br> "Casio FX-702P : pocket Basic" <br><br> "Casio, it counts"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RUSSIAN ADVERT - PAGE 3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Taras Ponomarev for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"You hesitate between two standards."<br> "Rank Xerox doesn't."</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RUSSIAN ADVERT - PAGE 1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Taras Ponomarev for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (SEPT. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Casio. Basic, it's magic"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1976 XMAS CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #2 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.primo.homeserver.hu/" target="_blank">PRIMO home-page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Welcome in the world of the "clean"-computers"<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>advert said:<br><br> No waiting for software<font color="#666666"> ...This exciting micro has fired the imagination of programmers who are busy developping new software to take full advantage of its performance capabilities...</font><br><br> No wait state<font color="#666666"> ...One advantage is the total elimination of memory access wait states so that interaction between the processor, RAM and disk drive is speeded up...</font><br><br> A free p-System for those who don't wait <font color="#666666"> ...A free p-System operating system and PASCAL, FORTRAN 77 and BASIC compilers which alone lists for $1475, we're now including free with the Sage II...</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>November 1986 price list:<br> Monochrome - Single drive: <b>£399</b> + VAT<br> Monochrome - Dual drive: <b>£499</b> + VAT<br> Colour - Single drive: <b>£549</b> + VAT<br> Colour - Dual drive: <b>£649</b> + VAT<br><br> Optional 10 MB hard disk: <b>£300</b> + VAT </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Valric-Laurène was the french importer of the Spectravideo SV-318.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (MAY 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (APR. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 464 - 6128 PERIPHERALS</strong></font><br><blockquote>From top left to bottom right:<br> - T.V. modulator for the CPC 6128<br> - Joystick with joystick adaptor<br> - T.V. modulator for the CPC 464<br> - Disc drive with interface and CP/M for CPC 464<br> - Speech synthesizer and stereo amplifier<br> - Additional disc drive<br> - Light pen with graphics software<br> - RS232 interface<br> - DMP 2000 dot printer</blockquote>

computer.coprocessor: TOM - 32 bit RISC CPU, 64 bit RISC POP (Programmable Object Processor), 64 bit RISC Blitter JERRY - 32 bit RISC DSP
computer.description:
In the early '90s Atari was approached by a company called Flair Technology. They claimed that they could design a new console that would be better than the SNES and Mega Drive. Atari were so impressed that they provided funding for a new company called Flair II. The newly formed company set about designing two new machines, the 32 bit Panther and the 64 bit Jaguar. After cancelling the Panther project, Atari contracted IBM to manufacture the Jaguar.
Released late in 1993, the Jaguar was marketed as the worlds first 64 bit console resulting in speculation as to whether really was. Containing five processors on three chips, only two of them were in fact 64 bit. A proprietary chip named TOM contained two 64 bit and one 32 bit processors. Primarily used for graphics processing TOM was also able to execute program code if desired. JERRY was another 32 bit proprietary chip responsible for sound processing while a 16 bit Motorola 68000 acted as a main controller, managing the other two chips and executing code.
Included with the Jaguar was one of the largest joypads ever made, with an 8-way d-pad, A, B and C buttons, pause and option buttons, and a 12 key numeric pad complete with star and hash keys! It also shipped with a free game, Cybermorph, which included a plastic overlay for the controller's number pad for a customised control layout.
The Jaguar's short lifespan came to an end when Atari merged with JTS in 1996. With sales of around just 150,000 units and poor publisher support, production ended soon after. This would be Atari's final machine (the Jaguar II was planned but never released), and a sad end to the company that once dominated the console market. Atari is now controlled by French company Infogrames, where it continues as a software publisher.
_________
Contributors: Ste (text & info)

emulator.description: Jaguar emulator for Windows, Linux, MacOS & BeOS
emulator.name: Virtual Jaguar

item.description: the cartridge||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> THE CARTRIDGE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an Alpine development cartridge (6 MB version) for the Atari Jaguar.</blockquote>

Box||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> BOX</strong></font><br><blockquote>The JagLink Interface allows the Atari Jaguar to be networked with another Jaguar unit. The JagLink Interface comes with two small boxes that allow you to network two Jaguars together. The JagLink box plugs into the DSP port on the back of the Jaguar. <br><br> Only three games took advantage of the JagLink: Air Cars, BattleSphere, and Doom: Evil Unleashed.</blockquote>

The unit||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> THE UNIT</strong></font><br><blockquote>In 1994 the Jaguar was facing competition from the 3DO and soon to be released PlayStation. Following in the footsteps of SEGA, Atari decided to create an ill advised CD based add-on for their system. This came in the form of a double speed CD-ROM drive capable of full-screen FMV, CD+G and audio CD playback. A non-standard format was used for storing data giving Jaguar CDs a larger than normal 790MB storage capacity. <br><br> Originally scheduled for release in 1994, several delays finally saw the machine released in late 1995. <br><br> Included in ROM was the Virtua Light Machine, which created visual effects to accompany the playback of audio CDs. <br><br> Ultimately the Jaguar CD suffered from the same poor sales and support as the Jaguar, with very few games released for the system. The unfortunate nickname of "the toilet" due to its shape probably didn't help either.</blockquote>

controller & box||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> CONTROLLER & BOX</strong></font><br><blockquote>Here is a rare Atari Jaguar 64-bit system PROCONTROLLER, with the addition of 2 shoulder buttons and 3 more thumb buttons for a total of 6, and a new slim-line ergonomic design. The new buttons map out to regular controller keypad buttons, so not only were games design for the procontroller able to use it, but it enhances the playability of pre-procontroller games too.</blockquote>

computer.name: Jaguar
computer.ports: 2 controller ports, RF out, Video edge connector (A/V output), Cartridge/Expansion port, DSP port
computer.power: External power supply unit, 9 volt DC
computer.sound: 2 DAC's, 16 bit stereo (Varying number of channels depending on software)
computer.vram: Shared with system RAM (All processors have direct access to RAM)
